Key Arguments: The current voluntary code on misinformation and disinformation is ineffective, and stronger, mandatory regulations are needed.
The ACMA should have more robust powers to enforce standards and remove offending content.
The exclusion of political materials from the legislation is problematic and undermines trust.
There is a need for greater clarity and consistency in the legislation to ensure it is effective.
Education programs targeting misinformation, especially among younger people, could be beneficial.
Main Themes: Importance of clarity and consistency in legislation
Role of education in combating misinformation
Notable Quotes: Voluntary codes are non-binding and rarely produce the results that are being sought.
The legislation should be clear-cut and demonstrate certainty that standards will be enforced.
It is disturbing that the Australian Government might create a contradiction in law that excludes its members from being subject to the same laws as others.
